trans-unit.source: Encrypt and Decrypt Blobs in Microsoft Azure Storage using Azure Key Vault
trans-unit.target: Encrypt and Decrypt Blobs in Microsoft Azure Storage using Azure Key Vault

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through how to encrypt and decrypt a blob using client-side encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage with Azure Key Vault
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through how to encrypt and decrypt a blob using client-side encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage with Azure Key Vault

trans-unit.source: This tutorial covers how to make use of client-side storage encryption - currently in preview - with Azure Key Vault - also currently in preview.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial covers how to make use of client-side storage encryption - currently in preview - with Azure Key Vault - also currently in preview.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through how to encrypt and decrypt a blob in a console application using these technologies.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through how to encrypt and decrypt a blob in a console application using these technologies.

trans-unit.source: Estimated time to complete: 20 minutes
trans-unit.target: Estimated time to complete: 20 minutes

trans-unit.source: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see <linkText>What is Azure Key Vault?</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see <linkText>What is Azure Key Vault?</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: For overview information about client-side encryption for Azure Storage, see <linkText>Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage – Preview</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For overview information about client-side encryption for Azure Storage, see <linkText>Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage – Preview</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure Storage account
trans-unit.target: An Azure Storage account

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 or later
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 or later

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: For an overview of Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage, see <linkText>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2015/04/29/getting-started-with-client-side-encryption-for-microsoft-azure-storage.aspx</linkText><title>Getting Started with Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage</title>
trans-unit.target: For an overview of Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage, see <linkText>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2015/04/29/getting-started-with-client-side-encryption-for-microsoft-azure-storage.aspx</linkText><title>Getting Started with Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage</title>

trans-unit.source: Here is the process as described in that blog post:
trans-unit.target: Here is the process as described in that blog post:

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage client SDK will generate a content encryption key (CEK) which is a one-time-use symmetric key.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage client SDK will generate a content encryption key (CEK) which is a one-time-use symmetric key.

trans-unit.source: User data is encrypted using this CEK.
trans-unit.target: User data is encrypted using this CEK.

trans-unit.source: The CEK is then wrapped (encrypted) using the key encryption key KEK.
trans-unit.target: The CEK is then wrapped (encrypted) using the key encryption key KEK.

trans-unit.source: The KEK is identified by a key identifier and can be an asymmetric key pair or a symmetric key and can be managed locally or stored in Azure Key Vaults.
trans-unit.target: The KEK is identified by a key identifier and can be an asymmetric key pair or a symmetric key and can be managed locally or stored in Azure Key Vaults.

trans-unit.source: The Storage client itself never has access to KEK.
trans-unit.target: The Storage client itself never has access to KEK.

trans-unit.source: It just invokes the key wrapping algorithm that is provided by Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: It just invokes the key wrapping algorithm that is provided by Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Users can choose to use custom providers for key wrapping/unwrapping if desired.
trans-unit.target: Users can choose to use custom providers for key wrapping/unwrapping if desired.

trans-unit.source: The encrypted data is then uploaded to the Azure Storage service.
trans-unit.target: The encrypted data is then uploaded to the Azure Storage service.

trans-unit.source: In order to proceed with this tutorial, you need to do the following which are outlined in the tutorial: <linkText>Get Started with Azure Key Vault</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: In order to proceed with this tutorial, you need to do the following which are outlined in the tutorial: <linkText>Get Started with Azure Key Vault</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Create a key vault
trans-unit.target: Create a key vault

trans-unit.source: Add a key or secret to the key vault
trans-unit.target: Add a key or secret to the key vault

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Authorize the application to use the key or secret
trans-unit.target: Authorize the application to use the key or secret

trans-unit.source: Make note of the ClientID and ClientSecret that were generated when registering an application with Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Make note of the ClientID and ClientSecret that were generated when registering an application with Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Create both a key in the key vault.
trans-unit.target: Create both a key in the key vault.

trans-unit.source: We will assume for the rest of the tutorial that you have used the following names: ContosoKeyVault and TestRSAKey1.
trans-unit.target: We will assume for the rest of the tutorial that you have used the following names: ContosoKeyVault and TestRSAKey1.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create a new Console Application.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create a new Console Application.

trans-unit.target: Add necessary nuget packages in the Package Manager Console:

trans-unit.target: Add AppSettings to the App.Config.

trans-unit.target: Add the following using statements and make sure to add a reference to System.Configuration to the project.

trans-unit.target: The following method is used by Key Vault classes that need to authenticate for access to your Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Key Vault Object Models
trans-unit.target: Key Vault Object Models

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand that there are actually two Key Vault object models to be aware of: one is based on the REST API (KeyVault namespace) and the other is an extension for client-side encryption.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand that there are actually two Key Vault object models to be aware of: one is based on the REST API (KeyVault namespace) and the other is an extension for client-side encryption.

trans-unit.source: The Key Vault Client interacts with the REST API and understands JSON Web Keys and Secrets for the two kinds of things that are contained in the Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: The Key Vault Client interacts with the REST API and understands JSON Web Keys and Secrets for the two kinds of things that are contained in the Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: The Key Vault Extensions are classes that seem specifically created for client-side encryption in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The Key Vault Extensions are classes that seem specifically created for client-side encryption in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: They contain an interface for keys - IKey - and classes based on the concept of a Key Resolver.
trans-unit.target: They contain an interface for keys - IKey - and classes based on the concept of a Key Resolver.

trans-unit.source: There are two implementations of IKey that you need to know: RSAKey and SymmetricKey.
trans-unit.target: There are two implementations of IKey that you need to know: RSAKey and SymmetricKey.

trans-unit.source: Now they happen to coincide with the things that are contained in a Key Vault, but at this point they are independent classes (so the Key and Secret retrieved by the Key Vault Client do not implement IKey).
trans-unit.target: Now they happen to coincide with the things that are contained in a Key Vault, but at this point they are independent classes (so the Key and Secret retrieved by the Key Vault Client do not implement IKey).

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to encrypt a Blob and upload it to your Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to encrypt a Blob and upload it to your Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: The ResolveKeyAsync method that is used returns an IKey.
trans-unit.target: The ResolveKeyAsync method that is used returns an IKey.

trans-unit.source: Following is a screenshot from the current Azure Management portal for a blob that has been encrypted using client-side encryption with a key stored in Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Following is a screenshot from the current Azure Management portal for a blob that has been encrypted using client-side encryption with a key stored in Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: The KeyId property is the URI for the key in Key Vault that acts as the key encryption key (KEK).
trans-unit.target: The KeyId property is the URI for the key in Key Vault that acts as the key encryption key (KEK).

trans-unit.source: The EncryptedKey property contains the encrypted version of the content encryption key (CEK).
trans-unit.target: The EncryptedKey property contains the encrypted version of the content encryption key (CEK).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot showing Blob metadata that includes encryption metadata</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot showing Blob metadata that includes encryption metadata</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you look at the BlobEncryptionPolicy constructor, you will see that it can accept a key and/or a resolver.
trans-unit.target: If you look at the BlobEncryptionPolicy constructor, you will see that it can accept a key and/or a resolver.

trans-unit.source: Be aware that right now you cannot use a resolver for encryption because it does not currently support a default key.
trans-unit.target: Be aware that right now you cannot use a resolver for encryption because it does not currently support a default key.

trans-unit.source: Decryption is really when the Resolver classes make sense.
trans-unit.target: Decryption is really when the Resolver classes make sense.

trans-unit.source: The ID of the key used for encryption is associated with the Blob in its metadata, so there is no reason for you to retrieve the key and remember the association between key and blob.
trans-unit.target: The ID of the key used for encryption is associated with the Blob in its metadata, so there is no reason for you to retrieve the key and remember the association between key and blob.

trans-unit.source: You just have to make sure that the key remains in the Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: You just have to make sure that the key remains in the Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: The private key of an RSA Key remains in Key Vault, so for decryption to occur the Encrypted Key from the blob metadata which contains the CEC (content encryption key) is sent to Key Vault for decryption.
trans-unit.target: The private key of an RSA Key remains in Key Vault, so for decryption to occur the Encrypted Key from the blob metadata which contains the CEC (content encryption key) is sent to Key Vault for decryption.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to decrypt the blob that you just uploaded.
trans-unit.target: Add the following to decrypt the blob that you just uploaded.

trans-unit.source: There are a couple of other kinds of Resolvers to make key management easier, including: AggregateKeyResolver and CachingKeyResolver.
trans-unit.target: There are a couple of other kinds of Resolvers to make key management easier, including: AggregateKeyResolver and CachingKeyResolver.

trans-unit.source: The way to use a Secret with client-side encryption is via the SymmetricKey class because a Secret is essentially a symmetric key.
trans-unit.target: The way to use a Secret with client-side encryption is via the SymmetricKey class because a Secret is essentially a symmetric key.

trans-unit.source: But, as noted above, a Secret in Key Vault does not map exactly to a SymmetricKey.
trans-unit.target: But, as noted above, a Secret in Key Vault does not map exactly to a SymmetricKey.

trans-unit.source: There are a few things to understand:
trans-unit.target: There are a few things to understand:

trans-unit.source: The key in a SymmetricKey has to be a fixed length: 128, 192, 256, 384, or 512 bits
trans-unit.target: The key in a SymmetricKey has to be a fixed length: 128, 192, 256, 384, or 512 bits

trans-unit.source: The key in a SymmetricKey should be Base64 encoded
trans-unit.target: The key in a SymmetricKey should be Base64 encoded

trans-unit.source: A Key Vault Secret that will be used as a SymmetricKey needs to have a Content Type of "application/octet-stream" in Key Vault
trans-unit.target: A Key Vault Secret that will be used as a SymmetricKey needs to have a Content Type of "application/octet-stream" in Key Vault

trans-unit.source: Here is an example in PowerShell of creating a Secret in Key Vault that can be used as a SymmetricKey:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example in PowerShell of creating a Secret in Key Vault that can be used as a SymmetricKey:

trans-unit.source: In your console application, you can use the same call as before to retrieve this Secret as a SymmetricKey.
trans-unit.target: In your console application, you can use the same call as before to retrieve this Secret as a SymmetricKey.

trans-unit.source: That's it.
trans-unit.target: That's it.

trans-unit.source: Enjoy!
trans-unit.target: Enjoy!
